posts.name: Johnny
posts.cooked: Hello everyone! I have a question about our robot arm. We are using a 1" wide x 28" long x 1/8" thick carbon fiber sheet and we want this arm to spin around in one direction and block it from rotating in the opposite direction. We want this to be very low profile and light. Therefore, we do not want to use a ratchet or the Versaplanetary Ratchet Kit. I was looking at one-way bearings, but the torque of the arm will be very high (since we are trying to lift about 20-40lbs of force, for that reason, I am worried about them slipping without the use of a thread locker or something similar. Does anyone have any suggestions for the best type of one-way bearing mechanism that can be mounted directly into the carbon fiber? We would prefer something off the shelf if possible. Thanks!

posts.name: Jim Forbes
posts.cooked:
Have you calculated the torque load on the bearing?

Also, you mention

FRCStudent:

We are using a 1" wide x 28" long x 1/8" thick carbon fiber sheet

I can’t really imagine this…is it a tube? or a flat sheet?

When we need to have something round like that, that has to take a lot of torque, and we want to be able to actually build it, steel is the material of choice.

posts.name: Johnny
posts.cooked:
Hello, Thank you for your help! I believe after calculating the torque, it should not exceed 50-60 ft-lbs. worth of torque.

This is what we were looking at:

McMaster-Carr is the complete source for your plant with over 595,000 products. 98% of products ordered ship from stock and deliver same or next day.

We were looking at carbon fiber because of the weight and low flex rate compared to steel or polycarbonate.

Is there a type of one-way bearing that you have ever used that has worked well? Thanks!

posts.name: Jim Forbes
posts.cooked:
We’ve never used a one way bearing in a robot, but I do see them in cars…in the starter drive, and in automatic and manual overdrive transmissions. These things are made of hardened steel.

I don’t understand how your mechanism would work…a sketch or render would be a big help…so I really can’t say…

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
FRCStudent:

We were looking at carbon fiber because of the weight and low flex rate compared to steel or polycarbonate.

Composites like CF (carbon fiber) and fiberglass are hazardous and messy to work with in spaces that are not outfitted for the work. Like measurably increasing lung cancer risk for all future occupants of the space kind of messy.

There’s also the whole practical issue of attaching to CF.

Aluminum, steel, and amorphous plastic like polycarb are both much better choices for >99% of teams.

Making some custom bends in a thin piece of aluminum (“roll the edge”, dimpling, other techniques) will get you similar enough stiffness to CF in a similar profile, and be at least a little easier and safer to attach to and work with…

posts.name: Nick Aarestad
posts.cooked:
We used a one way bearing on the winch for our constant-force spring powered shooter in 2014. It was a solid way to do and with a proper press fit held up like a champ all season and through almost two additional years of demo use. We mounted ours in a solid hunk of 1/2” thick aluminum, with a very precise bore.

One of the big things to consider in my opinion with a one way bearing is how you plan to reset the mechanism. We didn’t fully think this through then, and ended up pneumatically actuating the gearbox to disconnect the bevels holding the winch back. In retrospect, I suspect we could have found a cleaner way of doing this. You almost certainly do want to move the arm back at some point, unless you plan to use it only once all season.

Honestly I would probably suggest going a different route, but you likely will need an additional piece to hold the press fit bearing, and then attach that to your carbon fiber bit.

Good luck this season!

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked: Could you possibly use a bicycle freewheel or freehub? I’m not sure how you could adapt it but they will take quite a lot of torque

@SPang used a one way bearing in 2019 I believe. It was what allowed them to lift up their climb and drive forward and not worry about rolling backwards and tipping.

@SPang mind sharing?

posts.name: Patrick Freivald
posts.cooked: If you’re going to use needle bearings, you want the shaft they’re gripping to be hardened steel, and you want the tolerance as close as you can get it.

posts.name: snoman
posts.cooked:
Some recoil starters for small engines use a one-way bearing / clutch system is that what you’re thinking?

posts.name: Johnny
posts.cooked: That looks great because it could be mounted straight to the carbon fiber, but I fear that it is too big since I am looking for an Outer Diameter of less than one inch and something lighter than the starter clutch.

posts.name: Patrick Freivald
posts.cooked:
This should do the job for you.

Keep in mind that you’ll need a 3 cm hardened steel shaft and a way to press fit it. Also keep in mind that you’re simply not going to get it to rotate the other way, so re-setting your mechanism will take some thought.

Another option is to sacrifice a ratcheting wrench to be mounted on the axle that is stopped by a protruding shaft or aluminium frame. This was used extensively in 2017 and 2020 for climbers, the issue is finding a wrench that is rated for ~70ft*lbs and setting the wrench to turn in the right direction before matches.

posts.name: Thaddeus
posts.cooked:
FRCStudent:

carbon fiber

CF has the same density as steel (just a higher ultimate strength). Unless you’re going to use its properties in an interesting way (e.g. making a monocoque shell that transmits loads in efficient ways), and know what you’re doing, don’t fall for the CF meme. You’re just asking for splinters, annoyances, and empty bank account. We built light racecars out of aluminum (and still do); aluminum is wonderful.

And then you’re talking about… press fitting a bearing into the CF? With an adhesive that may-or-may-not be compatible with the epoxy resin holding the CF together…

FRCStudent:

the torque of the arm will be very high (since we are trying to lift about 20-40lbs of force, for that reason, I am worried about them slipping without the use of a thread locker or something similar.

McMaster-Carr ← needle-roller one-way bearings themselves will not support 20-40 pounds of force on a 28" lever arm.

I suppose there are these style: McMaster-Carr But then you’ll need to machine some press-fit housings and shafts.

What sort of machining resources do you have access to? Don’t sacrifice to the weight- and profile- saving gods if you don’t even have the equipment to do so.

posts.name: Jim Forbes
posts.cooked:
Thinking more about how to attach the bearing in a hole in a sheet of CF, a fillet of epoxy would probably keep it in place.

It’s still a crazy way to build a robot, I hope it works!

posts.name: Johnny
posts.cooked: Thank you for this reccomendation. We were looking at this one because of the small profile width compared to the other one, but the price is very expensive. Do you know if there a cheaper option?

posts.name: Patrick Freivald
posts.cooked:
You want small, lightweight, durable, rated for high torque, and cheap?

You’re not going to get it. Anything that satisfies even three of the first four requirements won’t satisfy the last, though in FRC terms, $80 isn’t that expensive.

Eighty bucks is about the price of a planetary gearbox with motor. The properly-machined chunk of hardened steel to use as a “puck” machined with a (presumably hex but maybe keyed) hole for a shaft might cost you nearly that much if you can’t make it in-house. So, depending on your capability, this bearing and “puck” will run you about the cost of one or two gearboxes.

If it’s worth it, spend the money. If it’s not, figure out which and how many of the first four requirements you’re willing to give on.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: Aerospace engineering mantra: “fast, cheap, good, and light. Pick up to 2.”

posts.name: Patrick Freivald
posts.cooked:
For what it can do and the size of the packaging, that bearing is fantastically cheap. “Fantastically cheap” can mean different things in engineering and on an FRC team, of course, but holding that kind of torque with that small a part is an impressive bit of techno-wizardry for $80.

We have a couple of smaller, less-torquey ones that we were looking to use on a PTO winch with a dog gear. Never did end up building the thing, but the option is really nice–your ratcheting mechanism is smaller than your dog gear, and weighs even less.
